editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Who can, I ≈øay, give a rea≈øon for this, if it be not true what I'm now in the Proof and Illu≈øtration of, viz. That Abraham's Covenant is our Covenant in the≈øe Days of the Go≈øpel, and Di≈øpen≈øed or Admini≈øtred in this Re≈øpect to us now, as of Old it was to him, and his Seed? This as I'm ≈øure it well agrees with the Doctrine of the Apo≈øtle, when he tells us in the forecited Gal. 3 13. That the Ble≈ø≈øing of Abraham is come on the Gentiles through Chri≈øt; So if it be not the rea≈øon why the Go≈øpel was thus Preach'd or Di≈øpen≈øed, for my part I know not what was.

Having laid this Foundation, I came to the more immediate An≈øwer of Mr. Wightman's Objection or Argument; taken as was ≈øaid from ≈øuch Scriptures as require Faith and Repentance in order to Bapti≈øm, and that we have no Example or In≈øtance in the Word of GOD of any Baptized, but ≈øuch as were ≈øo qualified: To which I replied to
this effect, That as for ≈øuch Scriptures as he had a reference to, and which, to many Per≈øons, ≈øeem'd to require Faith, Repentance, &c. as univer≈øally nece≈ø≈øary in order to Bapti≈øm, I could not but look upon ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction of them as very wrong, and great Abo≈øes of ≈øuch Scriptures When it is ≈øaid, He that Believes and is Baptized ≈øhall be Saved, &c they them≈øelves would ≈øay, It were a manife≈øt abu≈øe of the Text for any to ≈øay, It limited Salvation only to ≈øuch as actually Believed and were Baptized, and implied that no other than they ≈øhould be Saved; and yet this Conclu≈øion may as fairly be gathered from the Text, as that tho≈øe only that actually believe ≈øhould be Baptized. The one is as much in the Text as the other. And for this rea≈øon with ≈øome others, I told him that when we find Faith, Repentance, &c. required in ≈øome we read of Baptized, as nece≈ø≈øary in order to their Bapti≈øm, as, viz in the Three Thou≈øand Acts 2. the Eunuch, the Jaylour, &c. All that Con≈øi≈øtently with rea≈øon we could think was implied or taught us by ≈øuch in≈øtances was this, viz. That of tho≈øe that were Adult or grown to Years of Di≈øcretion, they only ≈øhould be Baptized in whom there is a vi≈øible Faith and Repentance: And this I told him we all Believed, and is what our daily Practice confirms: But
it being as I have ≈øhewed above, viz. That Abrahams Covenant is our Covenant in the≈øe days of the Go≈øpel, and Di≈øpen≈øed or Admini≈øtred with a Gracious E ‚Ä¢ tail upon the Seed or Children of vi≈øible Believers, as of Old it was on his Seed; and further, it being certain that the rea≈øon why ≈øuch as Believed and Repented of old were Baptized, was becau≈øe the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Faith & Repentance made them the Vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ble Heirs of the Promi≈øe or Covenant; we cou ‚Ä¢ d not but think our≈øelves oblig'd, in order to a regular Admini≈øtration of Bapti≈øm, not only to enquire and re≈øolve our≈øelves who were vi≈øible Believers, but al≈øo who they were whom this Gracious Entail of the Covenant did reach or extend is ≈øelf to; being from thence a≈ø≈øured the formal ground or rea≈øon of the Admini≈øtration of the Ordinance, is no le≈øs to be found in ≈øuch than in tho≈øe who in a Judgment or Charity do actually Believe, Repent, &c.

Hereto I added, That were I or any other Per≈øon or Per≈øons Sent into any part of the Heathen World, to gather Churches there, Vi≈øible Faith and Repentance being things nece≈ø≈øary in all Adult Per≈øons in order to their being Members of the vi≈øible Church, and Bapti≈øm being the Door of Admi≈ø≈øion into it, what Doctrine could we Preach to men, but this of the Apo≈øtles, viz. Believe
and be Baptized, Repent and be Baptized? We could Preach no other. But then when any Per≈øons did ≈øo Believe and Repent and were Baptized, and thereby became Members of the Vi≈øible Church, the Que≈øtion is, Whether Salvation does not thereupon come to their Hou≈øes or Families, as of old it did when Parents Believed and were Baptized; or in other words, whether they do not hereby bring in their Children with them, and convey a Member≈øhip to them al≈øo; making them thereby vi≈øibly Heirs of the Promi≈øe & Salvation together with them≈øelves? This I ≈øay, is a Que≈øtion needful to be Re≈øolved by and Per≈øons thus Employed; and ≈øo by You & Us, in order to our knowing what is Duty in the Admini≈øtration of Bapti≈øm. This Que≈øtion I know you re≈øolve in the Negative, and ≈øay; That the Per≈øons ≈øo Believing and Repenting, do not thereby bring Salvation to their Hou≈øes, or in other words do not bring their Seed or Children into a ≈øtate of Vi≈øible Salvation; but who, I pray, mu≈øt we believe, You or CHRIST and his Apo≈øtles? Do you or They Preach True Doctrine here? If Per≈øons ≈øo Believing and Repenting do not thus bring in their Children with them, as you ≈øay, then mo≈øt certainly CHRIST mi≈øs'd it when he told Za ‚Ä¢ cheus on his Faith and Repentance. that Salvation that very day came
to his Hou≈øe; and the Apo≈øtle Peter, when he told tho≈øe Penitents, Act II. That the Promi≈øe was to them & their Children, &c. And Paul, Gal. III. when he told the Galatians, That the Ble≈ø≈øing of Abraham is come on the Gentiles. If what you ≈øay be true, the≈øe Texts ≈øhould be Ras'd out of the Bible, for they are certainly Fal≈øe. Unle≈øs ≈øome good Rea≈øon can be given why the Faith & Repentance of Believers in that day ≈øhould bring Salvation to their Hou≈øes, and not in the pre≈øent; this for my own part I'm not able to do.

But now if on the other hand, it be true, that CHRIST and his Apo≈øtles are in the right in what they tell us in tho≈øe Texts, the unavoidable Con≈øequence of it will be, that the Infants of Vi≈øible Believers are to be Baptized.

Now to apply this to the Ca≈øe in hand, this was the very Ca≈øe with the Apo≈øtles & Evangeli≈øts, tho≈øe fir≈øt Mini≈øters of Chri≈øtianity; when they were ≈øent out to Preach the Go≈øpel and gather Churches, the whole World, excepting a few that were brought in by the Mini≈øtry of John the Bapti≈øt and CHRIST, were either Jews or Gentiles, and both of them Unbelievers, and therefore Enemies to CHRIST and his Go≈øpel, out of the≈øe they were ≈øent to gather Churches; and it being ≈øo, as I ≈øaid before, Vi≈øible Faith
& ‚Ä¢ epentance being the requi≈øites of Church. member≈øhip in all Adult Per≈øons, and bapti≈øm being the ordained Door of Admi≈ø≈øion into the Church, what other Doctrine could they Preach than this, viz. If thou Believe≈øt thou maye≈øt be Baptized, Repent and be Baptized, &c. But from hence to Infer that they Baptized no other, & that none are to be Baptized but ≈øuch as do ≈øo Repent & Believe, is a way of Arguing which I'm ≈øure no man that enjoys the ble≈ø≈øing of a Sound Mind will ju≈øtify: And I think enough has been ≈øaid to ≈øhow the Mon≈øtrou≈øne≈øs of it. And whereas you ≈øay, we have no Example or In≈øtance of their Baptizing any other than Adult Believers; I grant its true we have it not in Expre≈øs Terms ≈øaid they Baptized any Infants, Yet we have That that to us, and we think to any not blinded by Error & Prejudice, is Equivalent; when we are told that they Baptized Hou≈øholds or Families, viz. Lydia and her Hou≈øhold, the Jaylor & his Hou≈øhold, S ‚Ä¢ ep ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ as and his Hou≈øhold. Every Rational man will ≈øay, its ≈øtrange if in tho≈øe Three Families, there were no Children; Yea I think the Expre≈ø≈øions or Phra≈øes made u≈øe of, are Equivalent to a down-right A≈ø≈øertion, that there were; in as much as the Terms [Hou≈øe and Hou≈øhould,] in all Languages, & particularly in the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament, are
u≈øed to ≈øignify the Children of the Hou≈øe. See Gen. 30.30, & 45.18, 19 Numb 3.15. P≈øal. 115, 12.13, &c. Now it being thus, that the Apo≈øtle when ≈øpeaking of Bapti≈øm, ≈øhould borrow an Expre≈ø≈øion or Phra≈øe u≈øed in all Languages & particularly in the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament, to ≈øignify the Children of the Hou≈øe, we can't but look upon it Equivalent to a down-right A≈ø≈øertion, that there were Children in tho≈øe Hou≈øes; and for any one to ≈øay that notwith≈øtanding this, he would have us think there were no Children in them, is a thing ≈øo extravagantly wild that I think no Rational man in his Wits can be capable of it. The Sub≈øtance of this I then offer'd in an≈øwer to Mr Wightman's Objection or Argument; nor wa ‚Ä¢ any An≈øwer, that I remember made to it; ≈øave only that Mr. Wightman ≈øaid, That the Term Hou≈øe or Hou≈øhold, did not always ≈øignify the Children of the Hou≈øe, and to prove it In≈øtanced in Judges 16. ults To which I tho't it not needful to Return any thing; and ≈øo Di≈øcour≈øe ended on the Fir≈øt Que≈øtion. The Second was,

div.head: CHAP. II. QUEST. II. Whether Bapti≈øm by Sprinkling of Water on the Subject of it, be Law ul & Sufficient for the Ends of the In≈øtitution?
div.p: The intelligent Reader ≈øees this Que≈øtion was incautiou≈øly ≈øtated, the word [Sprinkling] u≈øed in it not being ≈øo expre≈ø≈øive of what we conceived to be the right Mode of Bapti≈øm, as the phra≈øes of Pouring on, or Wa≈øhing with Water. This was ob≈øerved to them before Entrance was made on the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of the Que≈øtion; and we let them know that by it we intended Baptizing by the Application of Water to the Face of the Subject, by Pouring it on or Wa≈øhing with it. Which being premi≈øed, the Po≈øition before me to prove, was this, Viz.

2. P. That Bapti≈øm by pouring on or wa≈øhing with Water, is Lawful and Sufficient for the Ends of the In ‚Ä¢ titution. And for Proof of this, I told Mr. Wightman & the A≈ø≈øembly, That I would fir≈øt mention ≈øome things on which, as grounds or rea≈øons we held our≈øelves Ju≈øticiable in Admini≈øtring Bapti≈øm in this mode or manner, and which, as we ≈øuppos'd, being laid together, would prove the Lawfulne≈øs of is; which having done, I would ≈øum them up together as a Medium in the Argument I ≈øhould offer for that end. They were th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe that follow, viz.

1. That the word Baptizo in the Greek, ≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ifi ‚Ä¢ Promi≈øcuou≈øly either Dipping into, or Wa≈øhing with Water, by the Application of it to the Subject. Se ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ elius renders it by the
Latin words Mergo & Lavo, i. e. to Dip or Wa≈øh; and its rendered in other Authors by the Latin words Madefacto, Lavo, Abluo, i. e. to Wet or Wa≈øh. Thus Budeus, Scapula, Pa≈øer and Grotius. And Criticks on the Greek Tongue tell us, that all Writers, both Heathen and Chri≈øtian, thus Promi≈øcuou≈øly u≈øe it. Leigh in his Critica Sacra tells us, That tho' the word be derived from Bapto, Tingo, i. e. to Dip, or Plunge into Water, and ≈øignifieth primarily ≈øuch a kind of Wa≈øhing as is u≈øed in Bucks where Linen is Plung'd or Dipt; yet its taken more largely for any kind of Wa≈øhing, Rin≈øing, or Clean≈øing, even where there is no Dipping at all. Vid. Critica Sacra on this Word, where al≈øo he gives many in≈øtances of it from Scripture. And this (viz. the Scripture u≈øe of this Word) is what at pre≈øent de≈øerves our more particular con≈øideration and enquiry. As to which, though I have not had time ≈øo to look into this matter as that I may be Po≈øitive in it; yet believe that upon a ≈øearch it will be found, that its no where ≈øo applied or u≈øed as nece≈ø≈øarily to ≈øignify Plunging or Dipping. I do not remember any Text where it nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øo ≈øignifies; but this I find, viz. That the Scripture when it would expre≈øs ≈øuch a kind of wa≈øhing or clean≈øing things as may be performed by pouring on or the Application of
Water to them, it then u≈øes the word Baptizo, but when it would expre≈øs a Plunging things under Water, it then u≈øes other Words. I'll give here ≈øome in≈øtances, Mark 7.4. Its u≈øed for wa≈øhing Hands and Cups, Pots, Brazen Ve≈ø≈øels and Tables. Where none can ≈øay it nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øignifies wa≈øhing or clean≈øing by immer≈øing or dipping tho≈øe things in Water, ≈øince they may as well be clean≈øed by pouring on, or applying Water to them. Of the Phari≈øees its there ≈øaid, That when they came from the Market, except they Wa≈øh they Eat not: In the Greek, Ean me Baptizontai, i. e. Except they are Baptized, but there rendred Except they Wa≈øh becau≈øe none can rationally under≈øtand the Baptizing there ≈øpoken of as ≈øignifying an Immer≈øion or Dipping of their whole Bodies. And many other things there be which they have received to hold, as Bapti≈ømous Poterion, i. e. according to the Greek the Bapti≈øms of Caps, but there rendered the Wa≈øhing of Cups, which may as well be done by the Application of Water to them, as by Plunging them into it. So Luke 11 28. Its ≈øaid of the Phari≈øee with whom Chri≈øt at a certain time Dined, that he Marvelled at him, Oti ou proton ebapti≈øthe pro tou Aristou, i. e. That he was not Baptized before Dinner; but there rendered that he had not fir≈øt Wa≈øhed before Dinner:
Becau≈øe none can rationally under≈øtand by it any more to be intended than the Wa≈øhing his Hands, which every one will ≈øay might as well have been done by pouring Water on them, as by dipping them into it. So Heb. 9.10. All the Ceremonial Wa≈øhings or Sprinklings are in the Greek called Bapti≈øms, (Diaphorois Bapti≈ømois) the words in the Original are rendred by Beza, diver≈øes Ablutionibus, i e Diver≈øe Wa≈øhings, as in our Tran≈ølation) many of which, ≈øays Pool in loc. were for the Prie≈øts, in their Services, and for others in performing theirs by them; ≈øome by Sprinkling with Blood, Exod. 29.20, 21. with Water. Numb. 8 7. and 19.9, to 19. ≈øome by wa≈øhing at the Brazen Laver, as the Prie≈øts, Exod. 29.4. and 30.17, to 22. ≈øo the Sprinkling of Healed Lepers, Lev 14.4, to 9 and the Purification of the Unclean. All which Ceremonies were performed by Sprinkling or Pouring on of Blood or Water, and not by an immer≈øion of the Body into it, and are therefore evidences that the word (Bapti≈øma, Bapti≈øm) is ≈øo far from being nece≈ø≈øarily under≈øtood to intend Dipping or Plunging, that in this place at lea≈øt, its nece≈ø≈øarily under≈øtood to intend no more than Sprinkling or Pouring on of Blood or Water.

But now on the other hand, when the Scripture would expre≈øs a Submer≈øion or covering
of the whole Body under Water, it u≈øes other words; hereby intimating that this is ≈øomething different from Bapti≈øm. The words it makes u≈øe of on this Occa≈øion are Katapontize≈øthai, D ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ i & Due≈øthai. See Exod. 15 4, 5. Where when it ≈øpeaks of Pharaoh and his Ho≈øt, their being Overwhelmed in the Red Sea, it u≈øes not the Original word for Baptizing, but the former of the words but now mentioned, and expre≈ø≈øes it thus, Kateponti≈øen en Eruthra Thala≈ø≈øe, i. e. They were Drowned or Overwhelmed in the Red Sea And Katedu≈øan eis buthon ho≈øi Lithos, i. e. They De≈øcended or Sank to the Bottom as a Stone. Whereas ≈øpeaking of the I≈øraelites who at the ≈øame time had only the Dewings of the Cloud, and Sprinklings of the Water of the Sea on them, u≈øes the word for Baptizing, expre≈ø≈øing it thus, Baptizanto en te Nephele, kai en te Thala≈ø≈øe, i. e As its rendred in our Bibles, They were Baptized in the Cloud and in the Sea. This I mentioned as the fir≈øt Ground or Rea≈øon on which we held our≈øelves Ju≈øtifiable in Admini≈øtring Bapti≈øm by Sprinkling or Pouring on of Water: But before I had quite fini≈øh'd this particular, Mr. Moderator Hitchcock, contrary to all Order and Laws of Di≈øputation, broke in upon me, and having bro't with him Mr. Symp≈øon, his Lexicon Anglo Graeco
Latinum Novi Te≈øtamenti, and turning to pag 17. where on the word Baptizo you have the following words, mo≈øtly from Leigh above mentioned, viz. To Baptize, Baptizo, Mat. 3.11. & 28.19. Mark 1 4, 8. The word tho' it be derived from Bapto to Dip or Plunge into the Water, and fignifies primarily ≈øuch a kind of Wa≈øhing as is u≈øed in Bucks where Linnen is Plung'd or Dipp'd, yet its taken more largely for any kind of Wa≈øhing, Rin≈øing, or Clean≈øing, even where there is no Dipping at all: As Mat. 3.11. & 20 28. Mark 7.4. & 10.38. Luke 3.16. Acts 1.5. & 11.16. 1 Cor. 10.2. Its put generally for Wa≈øhing, Luk. 11.38 Heb. 9 10. Mark 7.4. And Baptizing imports no more than Ablution or Wa≈øhing, as the Baptizing of Beds & Tables. Neither Mr. Adams, nor my ≈øelf, nor I ≈øuppo≈øe any other Per≈øon pre≈øent had any Su≈øpicion of his Unfairne≈øs or Di≈øhone≈øty in reading Mr. Symp≈øon, or that he had not ‚Ä¢ ead to us all he had ≈øaid on the word Baptizo, accordingly did not de≈øire of him a ≈øight of the Book; but ≈øince that Mr Adams having the Book in his Library, has look'd into it and found out the Di≈øhone≈øty of the Man, that he read not to us the whole his Author had ≈øaid on the word Baptizo; but only ≈øo much of it as was proper to per≈øwade us and
others, that he was again≈øt me, or at lea≈øt not ≈øo full with me in the account I had given of the import and u≈øe of the Word, as we ≈øhould have ≈øeen he was, had he read to us all he had ≈øaid. He read as far as that Clau≈øe, viz. Yet its taken more largely for any kind of Wa≈øhing, and ≈øtop'd there; whereas had he read all, every one would have ≈øeen Mr. Symp≈øon was fully with me in what I had ≈øaid. I mention not this through any Per≈øonal Prejudice again≈øt Mr. Hitchcock; I never, that I know of, ≈øaw his face before, but becau≈øe I think I owe this Ju≈øtice to my Reader, that he may ≈øee how little the≈øe in≈øpired Teachers, as they would be accounted, ≈øo frequent in many parts of the Land are to be depended on for light and guidance in our way, what little regard they have to Truth, and how unwilling they are it ≈øhould appear in ca≈øes where it will Reprove them, & Convince others of their Errors: I make no doubt but the re≈øt of his Brethren pre≈øent knew of the Cheat as well as he.

At the ≈øame time he read to us from The Port≈ømouth Di≈øpute, (as Mr. Adams informs me, the Title of the Book was) the Opinions of the A≈ø≈øembly of Divines, Mr. Perkins, Mr. Pool, and Mr. Baxter, in doing which al≈øo he repre≈øented them as of Opinion that dipping or plunging was the Primitive way of
Baptizing. To which he added, that if this was not the Primitive way, whence was it that the Eunuch was Oblig'd to come forth of his Chariot and go down with Philip into the Water in order to his being Baptized? What, ≈øaid he, had not ≈øo great an Officer of Queen Candace as he was, any Di≈øh or other Ve≈ø≈øel in his Chariot in which a little Water, enough for Sprinkling him, might have been fetch'd? this is very unlikely. He did not acquaint us with the particular Books of the fore-mentioned Authors from whence that Author had made tho≈øe Collections, nor have I to this day ever ≈øeen that Book; ≈øo that whether I have them by me, or if I have, whether that Author was Faithful in making his Collections from them, or Mr. Hitchcock read them as Hone≈øtly to us as he did Mr. Symp≈øon, I can't ≈øay.

However as I then wondered to hear tho≈øe two Venerable Names, viz POOL and BAXTER among them, e≈øpecially the la≈øt, con≈øidering what he ≈øays of Baptizing by Dipping, in his Plain Scripture Proof of Infant-Church-Member≈øhip and Bapti≈øm, ≈øo ≈øince Mr. Hitchcock's Di≈øhone≈øty re≈øpecting Mr. Symp≈øon is detected, as I am ≈øtrongly Su≈øpicious of ≈øome ≈øuch unfair-dealing as to all the Per≈øons above-named, either by that Author in making his Collections from them,
or in Mr. Hitchcock in reading tho≈øe Collections to us: So I find that as for Mr. Pool, and Mr. Baxter, they were greatly Abu≈øed or Mi≈ørepre≈øented in this matter. You will be convinc'd of this when I have cited to you ≈øome Pa≈ø≈øages from them. As for Mr. Pool, I find it was his Opinion that Dipping in Bapti≈øm was ≈øometimes u≈øed in the Ea≈øtern, Warmer parts of the World; in his Notes on Mat 3.5, 6. He has the≈øe words, viz. A great part of tho≈øe, i. e. of the dwellers in Jeru≈øalem, &c. who went out to hear John, were Baptized, i. e. Dipped in Jordan. But then as he adds in the ≈øame place, That it will not from hence follow that Dipping is E≈ø≈øential to Bapti≈øm, So in his Notes on Joh. 3.23. he as fully expre≈ø≈øes it to be his Opinion that this was not the con≈øtant way or manner of Baptizing in the Primitive times, but that ≈øometimes they Baptized then by applying or pouring on of Water. For there we have the≈øe words, viz. If ≈øome think it probable from this Text, that ≈øometimes the Apo≈øtles did Baptize by Dipping, yet it is at lea≈øt as Probable that they did not, or not con≈øtantly, from what we read of the Apo≈øtles Baptizing in Hou≈øes, Acts 9.17, 18 & 10.47, 48. & 16.33. From whence tis evident that as to Mr. Pool, had that Author or Mr. Hitchcock from him, given
this account of his Opinion in this matter, viz. That in the Primitive times, when Time, Place and other Circum≈øtances concurr'd, Bapti≈øm was performed by Dipping, but at other times when tho≈øe Circum≈øtances did not invite to it, 'twas performed by pouring on of Water. And that however it was then admini≈øtred, yet Dipping is not e≈ø≈øential to it. This had been an Hone≈øt Repre≈øentation of him in this matter; but for them, or either of them to take from him only what I but now cited from his Notes on Mat. 3.5, 6. with other like Pa≈ø≈øages, perhaps el≈øewhere in others of his Writings, at the ≈øame time pa≈ø≈øing by others, and hereupon repre≈øent him as of Opinion, not only that Dipping was the way of Baptizing only in u≈øe in the Primitive times, but as needful to be ob≈øerved now in order to the due Admini≈øtration of it, and hereby to bring him in as Patronizing an Error which never entred into his Heart, as Mr. Hitchcock then did; This I ≈øay is ≈øuch an abu≈øe of him, as can in no wi≈øe be ju≈øtified, and which I think no Man of Faith and Probity would have been Guilty of: But this is one of the u≈øual Refuges of Error, and what we may oft ≈øee it has recour≈øe to. In like manner that Mr. Baxter was no le≈øs Abu≈øed either by Mr. Hitchcock or his Author, you'll be put beyond all doubt when I have
cited from him ≈øome Pa≈ø≈øages which you may find with much more of the ≈øame Strain or Tenor, in his Plain Scripture Proof of Infants-Church-Member≈ø ‚Ä¢ ip and Bapti≈øm: Particularly from pag. 134 to 138, where he is Arguing again≈øt Baptizing by Dipping. Pag. 134. 2. Suppo≈øing they Dipp'd in Baptizing, yet as there are no moral rea≈øons in the Nature of the thing obliging others to do ≈øo too, ≈øo neither is there any po≈øitive Law obliging us to follow them in it, or determining that mode of Bapti≈øm. (2) There is no expre≈øs po≈øitive Law Obliging us to follow them in it; or Determining that mode of Bapti≈øm. Mat. 21.25.‚ÄîAnd if ≈øo, then ≈øo was the mode of it too: If therefore he Baptized by Dipping, this will infer

I know very well Mr Wightman & his Brethren ≈øay this mode, viz. Dipping, is of the E≈ø≈øence of Bapti≈øm, and that Bapti≈øm in any other way is no Bapti≈øm. But be≈øides that herein they ≈øeem not to me well to di≈øtingui≈øh between Entities & their Modes: Be≈øides this I ≈øay, I'm at a lo≈øs how they will prove it, any po≈øitive Law determining this mode of it I'm ≈øure there is none, nor can it I think be done from the import or meaning of the word in the Original: ≈øince (whatever it is, yet) we find it oft u≈øed there by the Spirit of God to ≈øignify Sprinkling or Wa≈øhing by pouring on or applying water to things, as well as dipping them. But enough of this, and more I think I need not add to make out this fir≈øt Particular, which is That Suppo≈øing Dipping was the way in which John the Bapti≈øt, the Apo≈øtles, Philip &c. did Baptize, yet this will not prove that all others are Obliged to Baptize in the ≈øame manner. The Second is,

[2] That tho' this he Suppo≈øed. yet it will be ≈øo far from inferring ≈øuch an Obligation lying on
others, that not with≈øtanding it may be ≈øinful in them to Immer≈øe or Dip tho≈øe they Baptize. This will be readily allowed for a Truth by all tho≈øe that know that many ca≈øes may be ≈øuppo≈øed, wherein there may be Moral Rea≈øons obliging Per≈øons to Swerve or Deviate from the Example of Holy men, in things wherein at other times and in other Circum≈øtances it were not only warrantable for them, but their duty to imitate or follow them. And this all tho≈øe mu≈øt know that are not ≈øo near to perfect Ideoti≈øm, as not to know that as hic & nunc i.e. time and place are Circum≈øtances in≈øeparable from all Actions, ≈øo that the Expediency or Inexpediency, and Con≈øequently the Lawfulne≈øs or Unlawfulne≈øs of them has a great dependance on tho≈øe Circum≈øtances. Actions good in them≈øelves and Expedient or Proper in one time or place, in another are Inexpedient; and it is a known Rule, Quicquid not Expedit, in Quantum non Expedit, non licet, i. e. What≈øoever is not Expedient, is ≈øo far forth Unlawful as it is Inexpedient. What I now ≈øay might be Illu≈øtrated by a Thou≈øand In≈øtances; but one ≈øhall ≈øuffice. And its that of the Corinthians, their going to Law before Unbelievers; Mr. Wightman no doubt will allow that the u≈øe of the Law for Recovery of mens ju≈øt Rights is lawful, yea

Now to apply this to the matter in Hand, viz. Dipping or Plunging in Bapti≈øm, as what I have now ≈øaid e≈øpecially takes place in the Po≈øitives of Religion, that have nothing moral in the Nature of them, and more e≈øpecially in the Undetermined Modes of tho≈øe Po≈øitives, ≈øo as to this particular of them of which I'm now ≈øpeaking, viz. If any of our Adver≈øaries ≈øay here, Suppo≈øing what I now ≈øay to be true, yet what Advantage

div.head: CHAP. III. QUEST. III Whether the Pre≈øent way of the Country in Maintaining Mini≈øters by a Publick Rate or Tax be Lawful?
div.p: I mu≈øt Adverti≈øe the Reader here, that in the Conference we had with Mr. Wightman and his Brethren before the Debate, he ≈øignified his di≈ølike of the Que≈øtion as thus ≈øtated, & declared him≈øelf ‚Ä¢ ully in Opinion with us, that Mini≈øters ought to be maintained, but this maintainance he tho't they ought to have from tho≈øe that heard them, and not ≈øuch as by Rea≈øon of Difference in Opinion from them, hold them≈øelves Obliged to withdraw from them. Que≈øt. Whether Lawful Authority have Right or Power to Compell ≈øuch to Contribute to
the Support of the E≈øtabli≈øhed Mini≈øtry of the Country, who by Rea≈øon of Difference in Opinion hold them≈øelves Obliged to withdraw from it? That the Pre≈øent way of the Country in Maintaining Mini≈øters by a Publick Rate or Tax is Lawful. In Order to which I told Mr. Hitchcock (for he took upon him the part of a Re≈øpondent here al≈øo) that I would fir≈øt Ob≈øerve to the A≈ø≈øembly what Evidence we have in Scripture, ‚Ä¢ hat its the Will of Ch ‚Ä¢ i≈øt that the Mini≈øtry he has Ordained in his Church ≈øhould be maintained, which having done, I would from thence offer an Argument more Immediately proving the Po≈øition before me. Accordingly I Ob≈øerved,

[1] That when Chri≈øt Ordained and ≈øent forth the Twelve and the Seventy, 'twas with this Expre≈øs Command or Charge, that they ≈øhould not Act in the Affair before them, at their own Expence or Co≈øt. Mat. 10 9.10. Luk 9.1. to 4. and 10.3, 4, 5. Where we

And at the ≈øame time, in Te≈øtimony of their Dete≈øtation of ≈øuch as did not Receive and freely Entertain them, to ≈øhake off the du≈øt of their feet again≈øt them. And further, he gives them to under≈øtand that in thus living upon tho≈øe among whom they came & were Received, they would not live on their Mercy or Charity, but that there was a Ju≈øtice in their being ≈øo Sub≈øi≈øted by them Mat. 10.10. For the workman is worthy of his meat.
[2] That the Apo≈øtle Paul in≈øi≈øts much on this matter, and by Arguments taken from various heads gives abundant proof of it. As, viz.

1. By an Argument taken from the Law of Nature and Common ju≈øtice, Thus 1 Tim. 5.18. Thou ≈øhalt not Muzzle the Mouth of the Ox that treadeth out the Corn, and, The Labourer is Worthy of his Meat: Where the Apo≈øtle alludes to that Ancient Practice among the Jews & diver≈øe other Nations of Treading out their Corn by the Feet of Oxen, in doing which, it was the Practice of ≈øome Covetous Per≈øons to have the Mouths of tho≈øe Bea≈øts Muzzled, that while they were

2. By an Argument taken from the rea≈øonable expectation of all Labourers in other affairs, Thus 1 Cor. 9. where ver. 6. having a≈ø≈øerted his right to forbear working with his Hands, and to demand ≈øupport from tho≈øe among whom he Laboured, he goes on with a proof of it by this Medium, and in≈øtances in the Souldier that goes not on a Warfare at his own Co≈øt, but expects Support & Wages from tho≈øe who Employ him. Yes ≈øurely, the rea≈øon of that Law reaches us with a greater force, that as he that Ploweth for another Ploweth in hope to get Bread for him≈øelf by his Labour, and he that Thre≈øheth for another, Thre≈øheth in hope of the ≈øame; ≈øo We that are the LORD's Plow-men, working together with Him in Plowing up the Fallow ground of Men's Hearts, & Sowing the Seeds of Righteou≈øne≈øs there; and His Thre≈øhers, (by our Labours, Exhortations and Arguments beating the Fruits of Good-works, to the Glory of GOD,

3. By an Argument taken from the di≈øparity or inequality of the things mutually imparted or given by Mini≈øters and their People that Support them. ver. 11. Mini≈øters give them not only a Quid for a Quo, i. e. a ju≈øt Compen≈øation for ≈øuch Support, but what is of much more value, there being a va≈øt Di≈øproportion in point of worth or excellence between the Spiritual things be≈øtowed by the Mini≈øter, & the Carnal things be≈øtowed by the People. Finally,

4. That it is the Will of CHRIST that the Go≈øpel Mini≈øtry ≈øhould have Support from the People, he proves from the care he took of his Mini≈øtry under the Law, ver. 13, 14. Do ye not know that they which Mini≈øter about Holy things Live of the things of the Temple? and they which wait at the Altar, are partakers with the Altar? Even ≈øo hath the
LORD Ordained, that they which Preach the Go≈øpel ≈øhould Live of the Go≈øpel. q d. The Will of CHRIST in the≈øe days of the New Te≈øtament is the ≈øame that it was during the time of the Old. He had a Mini≈øtry then, the Tribe of Levi, for which Tribe he Ordained a Live-lihood, Numb. 18.22. Deut. 1 ‚Ä¢ .9. and 18.1. So that they needed not to eat Bread by the Sweat of their Brows. The ca≈øe is the ≈øame now, its His Will and He has Ordained that tho≈øe who are taken off from their Worldly employments, and ≈øpend their time in the Study and Preaching of the Go≈øpel ≈øhould have a Live-lihood by their Labour. Having ob≈øerved the≈øe things, I told Mr. Hitchcock 'twas evident from the Scriptures cited, and what had been ≈øaid on them, that, ≈øuppo≈øing the E≈øtabli≈øhed Mini≈øtry of the Country is a true Go≈øpel Mini≈øtry, the Duty of Maintaining them is not among the number of meer Po≈øitives in Religion, but Moral, and ≈øuppo≈øing that to be ≈øo, for proof of the point before me I offered this Argument, Viz.

p.hi: That if Lawful Authority have Right or Power to Determine the ∆≤ndetermined Modes of Moral Duties, then the pre≈øent way of the Country in Maintaining Ministers by a Publick Rate or Tax is Lawful.

But Lawful Authority have Right or Power

div.p: To which I added, That the Support of Mini≈øters by a Publick Rate or Tax, was one Mode or Manner (among diver≈øe others) of Sub≈øi≈øting them, and that the Word of GOD tho' it had plac'd this among the number of Morals in Religion, yet had not Determined the Mode of it, or in what manner it ≈øhould be done, whether by Publick Rate or Tax, or Weekly Contribution, or any other, only in General, that it ≈øhould be done in ≈øome way or other: And that if in ≈øuch a ca≈øe where Moral Duties are thus Ciroum≈øtanc'd, Lawful Authority may Rightfully Interpo≈øe and Determine the Mode of them, then the pre≈øent way of the Country in Supporting Mini≈øters mu≈øt be Lawful, becau≈øe 'twas what ≈øuch Authority had by po≈øitive Law determined.
